customize.description: Likely you will just need to change the base might be helpful if you are moving to drasically different use cases.

mid-point.description: Steps in the scale below the mid-point get smaller, above get bigger

other-token-type.value: Will not export to Figma variables
other-token-type.description: But you can use math, and reference them across every token type so they are being used as a utility for that reason.

clarify.value: สูตรนี้เป็นการคำนวณค่าขนาดหรือระยะที่ “snap” เข้ากับระบบสเกลที่กำหนดไว้ โดยใช้ฟังก์ชัน roundTo, floor, และตัวแปรจากระบบ design token เช่น scale.unitless.xs, scale.multiplier, และ scale.factor ซึ่งมักใช้ในระบบ UI ที่ต้องการความเป๊ะในการจัดวางหรือขนาด เช่น spacing, sizing, หรือ typography
clarify.description:
1. scale.unitless.xs / scale.multiplier --> แปลงค่าขนาดที่ไม่มีหน่วย (เช่น 4, 8, 12) ให้เป็นค่าที่สัมพันธ์กับระบบสเกล

ตัวอย่าง: ถ้า xs = 12 และ multiplier = 4 → ได้ 3

2. roundTo(..., 0) --> ปัดเศษให้เป็นจำนวนเต็มที่ใกล้ที่สุด

roundTo(3.2, 0) → 3, roundTo(3.7, 0) → 4

3. floor(... / scale.factor) --> หารด้วย scale.factor แล้วปัดลงให้เป็น step ที่ต่ำที่สุด

ถ้า scale.factor = 0.25 → จะ snap เข้ากับ step เช่น 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1.0

4. * scale.factor --> คูณกลับเพื่อให้ได้ค่าที่ snap แล้วในระบบ scale

unitless-text-properties.description:
The unitless version of these properties are written this way because Figma doesn't support the preferred units, which are added to the description of the token if needed. 

For properties like lineHeight and letterSpacing which Figma only supports in percentage, an equation will be added in the typography composite token to support a smooth representation in Figma, however, they are to be coded in their preferred unit (em, unitless etc).

low.description: Used for hover or light highlight

medium.description: Used for focus or light overlay

high.description: Used for pressed or active state

overlay.description: Used for modal scrim or overlay background

thin.description: Thin border, subtle divider or small UI elements

thin-md.description: Thin-medium border for cards or secondary elements

regular.description: Regular border for buttons, input fields

medium.description: Medium-thick border for emphasis or highlighted components

thick.description: Thick border for strong emphasis, modals, banners

lv2.description: Low elevation for small raised elements like buttons.

lv3.description: Medium elevation for floating surfaces or popovers.

lv4.description: High elevation for floating surfaces or popovers.

lavel-1.description: Background blur used for translucent surfaces or overlays.

lavel-2.description: Stronger blur for modal or frosted glass surfaces.

supportingText.description: A remark is an auxiliary note or comment

remarkText.description: A remark is an auxiliary note or comment

H1.description: H1 is the primary heading level in a design system, used for the most important page headings. It establishes visual hierarchy and guides users to understand the main context of the screen or section.

H2.description: H2 is the secondary heading level used to organize content under the main heading (H1). It helps create structure and visual hierarchy, making sections easier to scan and understand.

H3.description: H3 is the tertiary heading level used to organize sub-sections under H2. It provides structure for detailed content and helps users scan information within a section.

H4.description: H4 is a smaller heading level used for grouping related fields or minor sub-sections. It often appears in forms or settings to label specific groups of inputs.

H5.description: H5 is typically used for labels or small headings that require slight emphasis over body text. It helps differentiate supporting information without dominating the layout.

H6.description: H6 is the smallest heading level, often used for helper text, remarks, or subtle annotations. It provides context or constraints without distracting from primary content.

Display.description: Very large text used for hero sections, marketing headlines, or prominent titles.

UI Text.description: UI Text refers to short, functional content elements in the interface—such as labels, buttons, tooltips, and system messages—designed to guide user interaction and ensure clarity.

Reding Text.description: Reading Text refers to the primary body content designed for comfortable, long-form reading. It emphasizes legibility, optimal line height, and accessible contrast for extended focus.

Caption.description: Small-sized text used for image descriptions, chart notes, or secondary annotations.

Micro.description: Extra-small text for helper messages, system notes, or subtle labels.

Title.description: Typography style used for main titles within the UI, such as section headers or page titles, to ensure clear hierarchy and readability.

Supporting Text.description: Small secondary text used to provide additional context, helper information, or clarifications.

Remark.description: Extra-small auxiliary text used for subtle notes, disclaimers, or less prominent comments.

subtle.description: Secondary background for cards or containers.

inverse.description: Dark background for headers or inverse sections.

success.description: Background color used for success states.

error.description: Background color used for error states.

warning.description: Background color used for warning states.

info.description: Background color used for informational states.

checked.description: Background color used for cehecked states.

disabled.description: Disabled background color for primary interactive elements.

primary.description: Primary text color for main content.

secondary.description: Secondary text color for less emphasis or placeholder text.

inverse.description: Text color used on dark backgrounds.

success.description: Text color used to indicate success state.

error.description: Text color used to indicate error state.

warning.description: Text color used to indicate warning state.

info.description: Text color used to indicate informational state.

disabled.description: Text color for disabled or inactive elements.

inverse.description: Icon color used on dark backgrounds.

default.description: Default border color for containers, inputs, and dividers.

focus.description: Border color used when an interactive element is focused.

subtle.description: Subtle border color for dividers or low-emphasis elements.

success.description: Border color used to indicate success state.

error.description: Border color used to indicate an error state.

warning.description: Border color used to indicate warning state.

selected.description: Border color for checked or active elements.

scrim.description: Dark overlay for modals or popups.

backdrop.description: Light backdrop used behind drawers or translucent layers.

transparent.description: use for transparent layers with start gradient

default.description: Default state color used for primary interactive elements like filled buttons or links.

focus.description: Focus state color for primary interactive elements, shown when receiving keyboard or programmatic focus.

pressed.description: Active state color for primary interactive elements when pressed.

disabled.description: Disabled background color for primary interactive elements.

hover.description: Used for hover state overlays or backgrounds

pressed.description: Used for pressed or active state overlays

sm.description: Adjust the column grid to fit the content and screen margins using Card grid, 2-column grid, or 3-column grid.

md.description: Adjust the column grid to fit the content and screen margins. Use Card grid, 2 Column grid and 3 Column grid

list.description: The list grid reject zone blocks touches in the interaction area

column.description: The column grid reject zone blocks touches in the interaction area

content.description: The Grip zone blocks palm touches and three-finger touches that may occur when the user is holding their phone.

description.value: Element-level spacing for small UI parts
